title: Mixed Hearing Loss with Facial Nerve Symptoms
chief_complaint: I hear a static sound in my left ear, and my hearing has gotten worse on that side. I also have some twitching in my face and lip on the left.

problem_summary.course: Progressive hearing loss; static tinnitus has been constant.
problem_summary.laterality: Left ear primarily; patient reported noticing loss in right ear but testing shows normal hearing there.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Static tinnitus (left), facial twitching (left lip, nose, eye). Yawning temporarily improves hearing for a few seconds.
problem_summary.functional_impact: Difficulty hearing in the left ear.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Evaluation of hearing loss and facial symptoms.

history.present_illness: Patient noted static sound in left ear 2 years ago without initial hearing loss. Six months later, hearing decreased. Yawning improves hearing briefly. Occasional twitching of left face/lip/nose/eye.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Right ear: Normal thresholds sloping to slight SNHL at 4kHz. Left ear: Slight to mild mixed hearing loss (250-2000 Hz) sloping to moderate/moderately-severe mixed loss in high frequencies. Significant air-bone gaps present in low frequencies despite normal tympanometry.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: Excellent word recognition scores bilaterally. SRTs in agreement with pure-tone averages.

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.key_findings: Normal Type A tympanograms bilaterally, indicating normal eardrum mobility and middle ear pressure.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Right ipsilateral reflexes present at 500-2000 Hz, absent at 4000 Hz. Left ipsilateral reflexes absent at all frequencies. Contralateral reflexes with probe in right ear (Stim L/Meas R) show elevated threshold at 1000 Hz only. Contralateral reflexes with probe in left ear (Stim R/Meas L) absent at all frequencies. Pattern suggests left efferent (facial nerve) pathway pathology.

numeric_results.Reflex Decay: CNT (Could Not Test) due to absent/elevated contralateral thresholds

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with a left mixed hearing loss characterized by low-frequency air-bone gaps and high-frequency sensorineural involvement. Speech understanding remains excellent. Despite the conductive component (air-bone gap), tympanometry is normal (Type A). Acoustic reflexes are absent when measured in the left ear (probe left), consistent with the reported facial twitching and suggesting pathology affecting the left facial nerve (VII) or middle ear mechanics not detected by tympanometry.
counseling_points: Your hearing test shows a mixed hearing loss in the left ear, meaning there is a combination of nerve loss and a problem with how sound is conducted through the ear.
Interestingly, your eardrum movement test is normal, but your acoustic reflexes (a muscle reaction in the ear) are absent on the left side.
Given the combination of your hearing loss pattern, the reflex results, and the facial twitching you reported, we need to investigate the nerve that controls facial movement and hearing.
I am referring you for an MRI to look closely at the structures of the inner ear and the facial nerve.
notes_for_actor: You are concerned about the twitching in your face (lip, nose, eye) on the left side.
Mention that yawning makes your hearing better for just a few seconds.
You might think you have hearing loss in the right ear too, but be relieved when told it is normal.
